description:
Crayon Shin-chan follows the wacky antics and adventures of five-year-old Shinnosuke "Shin" Nohara and his parents, neighbors, and friends and is set in Kasukabe, Saitama Prefecture, Japan.

Many of the jokes in the series stem from Shin-chan's occasionally weird, unnatural and inappropriate use of language, as well as from his inappropriate behavior. A typical gag involves Shin-chan confounding his parents by using the wrong phrase for the occasion; for example, saying "Welcome back!" instead of "I am back!" when he comes home.

During the beginning of the series, the TV show was mostly based on the storyline in the original manga. As the show progressed, more and more episodes became anime-original.

__Skills & Abilities:__ Certified nanny

__[Profile (Air Agency)](https://www.air-agency.co.jp/talent/woman_allianc/akiko_yajima) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akiko_Yajima) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/矢島晶子)__

Akiko Yajima is a Japanese voice actress. Her best-known role is as the title character Shinnosuke Nohara in the long-running anime series Crayon Shin-chan. On June 29, 2018, Akiko Yajima retired from her role as Shinnosuke Nohara's voice actress, with the role succeeded by [Yumiko Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/95539).

Non-anime roles:~!
• Alicia in "Valkyrie Profile 2: Silmeria" (VG)
• Anakin Skywalker in "Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace"
• Annie Bars in "Tales of Rebirth" (VG)
• Ben Seaver (early childhood) in "Growing Pains" (live-action TV series)
• Charlie Brown in "Peanuts" (animated series and specials)
• Chobi in "Final Fantasy: Unlimited After 2" (drama CD)
• Chobi in "Final Fantasy: Unlimited Before" (drama CD)
• Gaspard in ".hack//G.U. Vol. 2: Kimi Omou Koe" (VG)
• Gaspard in ".hack//G.U. Vol. 3: Aruku you na Hayasa de" (VG)
• Gaspard in ".hack//G.U. Vol.1 Saitan" (VG)
• Matsuoka Kyouko in "Kirai ni Narisou" (Drama CD)
• Maya Amano in "Persona 2: Batsu" (VG)
• Niigi Gorgeous Blue in "Castle Shikigami 2" (VG)
• Spyro in "Spyro the Dragon" (VG)
• Teddy in "Full House" (live-action TV series)!~

Laura Dawn Bailey is an American actress and voice actress. Best known for her anime roles (at first, Funimation titles but she has definitely moved on), she has also supplied voices in video games and worked as staff on several anime series. She's become one of the most prolific female voice actors in the AAA gaming industry since 2010.

Some of her best known anime roles are Lust in Fullmetal Alchemist, Young Trunks in Dragon Ball Z, Maka Albarn in Soul Eater, Tohru Honda in Fruits Basket, Sana Kurata in Kodocha, and Shin Nohara in the English dub of Crayon Shin-chan.

She is married to fellow voice actor [Travis Willingham](https://anilist.co/staff/95026/Travis-Willingham), and they have one son, Ronin.

Bailey primarily does video game voice overs and western animation nowadays, rarely getting any new anime roles, generally only reprising roles when she does anime. If she does get a new anime role, it's usually with Studiopolis.

Featured on "Critical Role."

[Website](http://www.laurabaileyvo.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/LauraBaileyVO)

__Cousin:__ [Aaron Dismuke](https://anilist.co/staff/95254/Aaron-Dismuke)

__Justin Ryan Cook__ is an American voice actor, producer, line producer, ADR director and enginner who works for FUNimation.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/brinapalencia) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/brinakins/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/brina.palencia.7)

Brina Michelle Palencia is an American voice actress who has voiced a number of English-language versions of characters featured in anime. She's a graduate of University of North Texas. [Gino Palencia](https://anilist.co/staff/104093), her brother, also works for Funimation.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/臼井儀人)

A mangaka known for the popular [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/manga/32435/) series.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/masaakiyuasa)

An acclaimed anime director known for his wild, freeform style. 

After graduating from the Kyushu Sangyo University's Faculty of Arts in 1987 he joined studio [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/Ajiado), initially as in-betweener but rapidly moving to key animation. 

In the first part of his career Yuasa established himself as an idiosyncratic creator while working on several child friendly anime, such as [Chibi Maruko-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/951/Chibi-Marukochan/) and [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2677/Doraemon-Nobitas-Animal-Planet/), but especially on [Crayon Shin-chan](https://anilist.co/anime/966/Shin-Chan/), a project he was involved with for most of the '90s. 

One of his breakthrough roles in this period was his participation on the second part of [The Hakkenden](https://anilist.co/anime/12715/The-Hakkenden-Legend-of-the-Dog-Warriors-Part-2/), working as animation director under [Shinya Oohira](https://anilist.co/staff/103893/Shinya-Oohira)'s direction. This OVA was an important outing of the '90s, uniting many veteran artists and talented newcomers. 

He debuted as director on [Mind Game](https://anilist.co/anime/875/Mind-Game/), an abstract piece combining animation and live-action footage, winning the 2004 Japan Media Arts Festival (overcoming even Hayao Miyazaki's [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/)), and earning [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/Yoshiyuki-Tomino)'s praise, who acted as the chief judge. After Mind Game Yuasa spent several years at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) working on various projects. In 2013, he founded [Science SARU](https://anilist.co/studio/6145/Science-SARU) alongside his close affiliate [Eun-Yeong Choi](https://anilist.co/staff/115088/EunYeong-Choi).

On March 25, 2020 it was announced Yuasa stepped down as the CEO of Science SARU. He would work there as director until the completion of his latest Movie, [Inu-Oh](https://anilist.co/anime/109928/InuOh/), and would later cease any affiliation with the studio.

On February 17, 2025 it was announced that Yuasa would launch of his own animation studio, ame pippin. Their debut project would be the film [Daisy's Life](https://anilist.co/anime/190574/Hinagiku-no-Jinsei/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/masaakiyuasa)

The founder and former representative director of [Funimation](https://anilist.co/studio/102/).

**Non-anime roles:**
- Policeman in "Chuck E. Cheese in the Galaxy 5000"

__Kumi Koda__ is a Japanese singer from Kyoto, known for her urban and R&B songs.

After debuting with the single "Take Back" in December 2000, Koda gained fame in March 2003 when the songs from her seventh single, "Real Emotion/1000 no Kotoba", were used as themes for the video game Final Fantasy X-2. Her popularity grew with the release of her fourth studio album Secret (2005), her sixteenth single "Butterfly" (2005), and her first greatest hits album Best: First Things (2005), reaching the number-three, number-two, and number-one spots respectively.

Though her early releases presented a conservative, quiet image, since as early as 2003 Koda has adopted a sexier and more provocative style. Because of this image, she has become a fashion leader among young women, setting trends such as the ero-kakkoii style. In 2006 and 2007, Oricon named Koda as the top selling artist of the year.

(Source: Wikipedia)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/浜名孝行)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/浜名孝行)

__Daisuke Asakura__, alternatively known as DA, is a Japanese vocalist, music producer, orchestrator, composer and arranger.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/zachbolton6)

Also a line producer.

An award winning freelance director.

__[Website](https://www.okuiaki.com/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/aikioku)__ | __[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/okuiaki)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/akiokui/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCwuaxsKnFmwICYMXus9oGTg)__

__Birthplace:__ Itami, Hyougo Prefecture, Japan.

__Biography:__
Aki Okui is a Japanese veteran singer-songwriter under record labels Warner Music Japan (1993-), Star Child (2000-), BUTTERFLY (2001-), Media Factory (2010-) and Capriccio Music Records (2019-), who has previously been under record labels Wea Japan (1994-1997), Infinity Records (2003-2006) and Livemaster Records (2007-2009). 

She is a singer who dates all the way back to her debut single, "Gin no Spoon de" in November of 1993 through record label Warner Music Japan. Her career spans a vast territory including 10 full albums, 1 mini album and 11 single releases. Unlike many Japanese singers, she still retains her Kansai dialect (western Japan) and has an impressive falsetto capable of wooing the most trained of ears. Her incredible voice has found its way on many anime titles including Gundam, Crayon Shinchan, as well as lesser known titles.

AKB48 is an all-female Japanese theater/idol group. AKB48 currently consists of 83 members divided into five teams: Team A, Team K, Team B, Team 4, Team 8, and the Kenkyusei or trainees who usually substitute for missing members.

Unlike other idol groups in Japan, AKB48 are theatre-based and have their own theatre in Akihabara (a district in Tokyo, Japan) where they perform once every weekday, and twice on both Saturday and Sunday. The theatre is set up on the 8th floor of Don Quixote. As of 2012, they had 7 releases, or 6 consecutive singles, sold 1 million in the first or second day as well as top Japan popular download site Recochoku. They became the first female group to win Japan prestigious Record Award in 2011 for their song Flying Get. They also became the first artist to win 4 awards at Billboard Japan award, best artist, top pop act, best single of the year, best single sales of the year.

__Date of Birth:__ 1953 
__Place of Birth:__ Japan 

A music composer and member of the Japanese Society for Rights of Authors, Composers and Publishers (JASRAC). He graduated from the Department of Literature at Chuo University and joined afterwards Nippon Columbia as music director. 

(Source: AniDB)

node.description: official website | twitter (pamyurin) | instagram (kyarypappa) Kiriko Takemura (竹村桐子), born January 29, 1993 in Tanashi, Tokyo, professionally known as Kyary Pamyu Pamyu is a Japanese singer, model, and blogger. Her public image is associated with Japan's kawaii and decora culture, centered in the famous Harajuku neighborhood of Tokyo. Pamyu Pamyu's music is produced by Yasutaka Nakata of electronic music duo CAPSULE. Though most of her success as a recording artist has been in Asia, she has gained popularity in the west in part due to viral internet videos. Media outlets have referred to Pamyu Pamyu as "Harajuku's Pop Princess", and she has been photographed for magazines such as Dazed & Confused. In 2013, she signed a distribution deal with Sire Records to release her material in the United States. Despite being raised in a traditional strict household and her very critical mother, Takemura started as a fashion blogger and then began her professional career as a model for Harajuku fashion magazines such as Kera! and Zipper. She would find her stage name after a friend called her "Kyari" for embracing Western culture and looking like a foreign girl. The name stuck, but eventually Pamyu Pamyu was added on because it sounded cute. Takemura would eventually meet Yasutaka Nakata at his club event. Nakata took interest in her because of her involvement in the fashion industry and encouraged her to debut as a singer. Career Her first promo single, Pon Pon Pon was an immediate success, leading to it being reported on by MTV and The Huffington Post. She released her debut album, moshi moshi Harajuku, in August 2011. A week later she released an autobiography about her rise to fame titled, Oh! My God!! Harajuku Girl. Her debut full-length album, Pamyu Pamyu Revolution, was released in May 2012. She toured around Japan in 2012, and went on to tour worldwide on the 100% KPP World Tour that began in February 2013. She received a great deal of media attention from Asian and Western outlets alike, with many reviewers highly praising her music and exciting aesthetic. Significant music publications like MTV, The Fader, and Stereogum wrote such articles. She was also interviewed by several news channels such as the Swedish Svenska Dagbladet, the French Le Petit Journal, and The Wall Street Journal. Pamyu Pamyu's second studio album, Nanda Collection was released in June 2013. Several months later she announced a second world tour. She would continue to receive much attention from the worldwide press and positive reviews from music publications. She would release her third studio album, Pika Pika Fantajin in July 2014. She held a nation-wide arena hall tour. In January 2015, the Hollywood Reporter mentioned her as one of the major recent sellers for Warner Music Group alongside world stars such as Coldplay and Ed Sheeran. In May 2016, a compilation album, KPP Best was released, with a third world tour following closely after. She remained greatly involved in other endeavors, such as fashion and art exhibitions. In 2017 Pamyu Pamyu would perform 6 more international concerts, after which she stated in an interview with Billboard Japan that her style had evolved, but hoped to maintain the basic 'kawaii' style her music and style was known for. In September 2018 she released her first studio album in four years: Japamyu Pamyu Pamyu has mentioned that she's into anime and manga. She called Crayon Shin-chan her favorite anime and has also mentioned she's a Vocaloid fan.
